column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/11/dianna-russini-coaches-nfl-suits-link-bill-belichick-to-bucs-and-other-teams/|Dianna Russini: Coaches/NFL Suits Link Bill Belichick To Bucs (And Other Teams)|Could the Bucs have a new coach next year? Would that new coach have the second-most wins in NFL history? Some league insiders think that is a real possibility. One speed bump stands in the way: Todd Bowles is very much still employed by Tampa Bay. And if he is able to rally his troops to reach the playoffs in the remaining seven games
column2: it would be a stretch to think Bowles would get run. However
column3: from a few coaches and NFL suits who spoke to Dianna Russini of The Athletic
column4: if the Bucs’ season goes south in the next two months
column5: a long shadow will hang over One Buc Palace. That would be the silhouette of Bill Belichick. The former Browns and Patriots coach lurks. He has six rings to his resume as a head coach and is largely believed to be seeking a new team after parting ways with the Patriots in January. Russini asked coaches and NFL shot-callers where Belichick may land. While Jacksonville was often mentioned
column7: Russini typed. One common answer was the Jacksonville Jaguars. In a recent episode of the “Scoop City” podcast
column8: my co-host Chase Daniel and I discussed the possibility of Belichick taking over Jacksonville in 2025
column9: should Doug Pederson get fired. While Belichick has maintained a strong relationship with Jaguars ownership
column10: it’s anticipated he would seek changes in the front office
column11: particularly regarding current general manager Trent Baalke. The other two teams that came up frequently: The Dallas Cowboys and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers (should those jobs open up). Of course
column12: Belichick has been dropping hints himself in his many media responsibilities this year. Earlier this season on “Inside the NFL
column13: ” Belichick enthusiastically said of the Bucs’ offense
column14: “I love Baker Mayfield.” And recently on the Manning Bros. show
column15: Belichick spoke glowingly of Bucs AC/DC-loving general manager Jason Licht who worked with Belichick in New England. Belichick
column17: said Bucs left tackle Tristan Wirfs was the best at his position this season. So there is something for Bucs fans and Joe’s readers to chew on as they prep for the Bucs-Giants game tomorrow at 1 p.m. Ira Kaufman Demands The Floor To Clarify His Stance On Jason Licht

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/11/another-setback-for-simeon-rice/|Another Setback For Simeon Rice|BY IRA KAUFMAN Simeon Rice’s Hall of Fame case remains on slow boil. Since sacks became an official statistic in 1982
column2: only 20 players have deposited quarterbacks on their rumps more often than No. 97
column3: a terror off the right edge in Tampa Bay for six seasons. Yet Rice’s name doesn’t trigger much enthusiasm among the 49 selectors who decide who will be fitted for gold jackets in Canton. It’s an enduring mystery because Rice has been eligible for induction since 2013. In that time
column4: only twice has he made the list of 25 semifinalists. He advanced to the top 25 in 2018 and 2020
column5: but was eliminated both times in the cutdown to the final 15. This month
column6: Rice once again was not among the group of 25 semifinalists
column7: which includes edge rushers Jared Allen
column8: Terrell Suggs and Robert Mathis. Only the 15 finalists get to hear their case heard
column9: so Rice’s compelling resume remains buried in the shadows. If you saw Simeon Rice play
column10: whether it was with the Cardinals or Bucs
column11: you know he was a consistent game-wrecker. From 1998-2005
column12: his 101.5 sacks were tops in the league. He was very good in Arizona and even better in Tampa
column16: 37 passes defended and 67 tackles for loss in only 87 games before a shoulder injury led to his release in 2007. When the games counted the most
column17: Rice was at the top of his game. In five postseason matchups as a Buccaneer
column18: Rice posted seven sacks and four forced fumbles. He could easily have been named MVP of Tampa Bay’s 2003 Super Bowl victory
column19: but the league wanted the media votes in early and Dexter Jackson had already made his mark with a pair of interceptions. During his Hall of Fame speech in 2014
column20: Derrick Brooks lauded Rice as “one of the best
column21: if not the best pass rushers of his generation.” So what’s the holdup? Not every outstanding pass rusher sails into Canton. Allen has been waiting his turn
column22: despite ranking 12th all-time with 136 career sacks. Leslie O’Neal finished with 132.5 sacks
column24: yet he never made it into the discussion room as a modern-era candidate. He’s now languishing in the senior abyss
column25: with dozens of other outstanding candidates waiting their turn. The same fate could befall Rice
column26: who was the second-fastest player to 100 sacks behind Reggie White. “There’s no Hall of Fame without me in it
column27: ” Rice says. “I dominated when I played. There was nobody better at my position — nobody.” That might be hyperbole
column28: but Rice isn’t far off. He was too athletic and smart for most left tackles to handle. And with Warren Sapp aligned off Rice’s left shoulder in Tampa Bay’s 4-man front
column29: offensive coordinators faced an immense challenge in keeping quarterbacks upright. You can’t blame Rice for being frustrated. At the age of 50
column30: he knows his Hall of Fame chances appear to be slipping away. The Hall of Fame panel is getting younger and soon there will be voters who never saw Rice come off the right edge with fury and precision. There were many times when I saw Rice running laps around the field well after practice had ended. He kept himself in peak condition — and that’s why his shoulder injury in 2006 was so surprising. When the Bucs released him the following summer
column31: it seemed to be a rash move
column33: Rice’s glorious career was over. He took a course at the New York Film Academy in 2009 and directed some projects
column34: but he never quite got football out of his blood. In 2017
column35: he talked about a career comeback with the Buccaneers. He was only half-joking. Rice dealt with bouts of depression after his retirement
column36: but he seems to be in a good place. The Glazers should seriously consider Rice for the Buccaneer Ring of Honor. He was the final piece of a historic defense. If his case is ever heard by Hall of Fame voters and he’s passed over
column37: Rice can live with that. Somehow
column39: he’s got to get into the room where it happens. Food
column40: Fun & More For Sunday’s Bucs-Giants Game Bring canned foods to help local food banks and/or a toy for a local child. Bill Currie Ford
column41: a mile north of the stadium on Dale Mabry Highway
column42: is the place to watch the Bucs on Sunday.  The watch party runs from noon through the end of the game. Come anytime!! Martin Gramatica will be there all day and Bill Currie Ford will feed you!
